inlineContent.text: known as arrays, sets, and dictionaries,
Arrays are ordered collections of values.
Sets are unordered collections of unique values.
Dictionaries are unordered collections of key-value associations.
Arrays, sets, and dictionaries in Swift are always clear about
the types of values and keys that they can store.
This means that you can‚Äôt insert a value of the wrong type
It also means you can be confident about the type of values
you will retrieve from a collection.
Swift‚Äôs array, set, and dictionary types are implemented as
For more about generic types and collections, see
If you create an array, a set, or a dictionary, and assign it to a variable,
the collection that‚Äôs created will be
This means that you can change (or
by adding, removing, or changing items in the collection.
If you assign an array, a set, or a dictionary to a constant,
and its size and contents can‚Äôt be changed.
It‚Äôs good practice to create immutable collections
in all cases where the collection doesn‚Äôt need to change.
Doing so makes it easier for you to reason about your code
and enables the Swift compiler to optimize the performance of
stores values of the same type in an ordered list.
The same value can appear in an array multiple times at different positions.

You can also write the type of an array in shorthand form as
Although the two forms are functionally identical,
and is used throughout this guide when referring to the type of an array.

code: print("someInts is of type [Int] with \(someInts.count) items.")
// Prints "someInts is of type [Int] with 0 items."

This method removes the item at the specified index and returns the removed item

code: print("letters is of type Set<Character> with \(letters.count) items.")

Alternatively, if the context already provides type information,
such as a function argument or an already typed variable or constant,
you can create an empty set with an empty array literal:

// letters is now an empty set, but is still of type Set<Character>

You can efficiently perform fundamental set operations,
such as combining two sets together,
determining which values two sets have in common,
or determining whether two sets contain all, some, or none of the same values.
The illustration below depicts two sets ‚Äî
with the results of various set operations represented by the shaded regions.

in a collection with no defined ordering.
Each value is associated with a unique
which acts as an identifier for that value within the dictionary.
Unlike items in an array, items in a dictionary don‚Äôt have a specified order.
You use a dictionary when you need to look up values based on their identifier,
in much the same way that a real-world dictionary is used to look up
the definition for a particular word.
The type of a Swift dictionary is written in full as
is the type of value that can be used as a dictionary key,
is the type of value that the dictionary stores for those keys.
You can also write the type of a dictionary in shorthand form as
Although the two forms are functionally identical,
and is used throughout this guide when referring to the type of a dictionary.
of a certain type by using initializer syntax:

code: // namesOfIntegers is an empty [Int: String] dictionary

inlineContent.text: You access and modify a dictionary through its methods and properties,
As with an array, you find out the number of items in a
as a shortcut for checking whether the
You can add a new item to a dictionary with subscript syntax.
Use a new key of the appropriate type as the subscript index,
and assign a new value of the appropriate type:

code: // the airports dictionary now contains 3 items

inlineContent.text: You can also use subscript syntax to change the value associated with a particular key:

code: // the value for "LHR" has been changed to "London Heathrow"

inlineContent.text: to set or update the value for a particular key.
Like the subscript examples above, the
sets a value for a key if none exists,
or updates the value if that key already exists.
This enables you to check whether or not an update took place.
the method returns a value of type
This optional value contains the old value for that key if one existed before the update,

code: if let oldValue = airports.updateValue("Dublin Airport", forKey: "DUB") {
print("The old value for DUB was \(oldValue).")
// Prints "The old value for DUB was Dublin."

inlineContent.text: You can also use subscript syntax to retrieve a value from the dictionary for a particular key.
Because it‚Äôs possible to request a key for which no value exists,
a dictionary‚Äôs subscript returns an optional value of the dictionary‚Äôs value type.
If the dictionary contains a value for the requested key,
the subscript returns an optional value containing the existing value for that key.

code: print("The name of the airport is \(airportName).")
print("That airport isn't in the airports dictionary.")
// Prints "The name of the airport is Dublin Airport."

inlineContent.text: You can use subscript syntax to remove a key-value pair from a dictionary

code: // "Apple International" isn't the real airport for APL, so delete it
// APL has now been removed from the dictionary

This method removes the key-value pair if it exists

abstract.text: Organize data using arrays, sets, and dictionaries.
Define requirements that conforming types must implement.
Write code that works for multiple types and specify requirements for those types.
Model custom types that define a list of possible values.
